title: String Basics
content:
## What are Strings?

Strings are sequences of characters used to store and manipulate text.

```python
name = "Alice"
message = 'Hello, World!'
empty = ""
```

## Creating Strings

### Single and Double Quotes

```python
# Both work identically
single = 'Hello'
double = "Hello"

# Use one to contain the other
quote1 = "It's a beautiful day"
quote2 = 'He said "Hello"'

# Or escape quotes
quote3 = 'It\'s a beautiful day'
quote4 = "He said \"Hello\""
```

### Multi-line Strings

```python
# Triple quotes for multi-line
multi = """This is a
multi-line
string."""

# Also works with single quotes
multi2 = '''Line 1
Line 2
Line 3'''

# Backslash to continue on next line (no newline)
long_string = "This is a very long string "\
              "that continues on the next line."
```

### Raw Strings

```python
# Raw strings ignore escape sequences
path = r"C:\Users\name\documents"
print(path)  # C:\Users\name\documents

regex = r"\d+\.\d+"  # Useful for regex patterns
```

## String Indexing

Strings are sequences with indices starting at 0:

```python
text = "Python"
#       012345
#      -654321 (negative indices)

print(text[0])    # 'P' (first character)
print(text[1])    # 'y'
print(text[-1])   # 'n' (last character)
print(text[-2])   # 'o' (second to last)
```

## String Slicing

```python
text = "Hello, World!"

# Syntax: string[start:end:step]
print(text[0:5])     # 'Hello' (characters 0-4)
print(text[7:12])    # 'World'
print(text[:5])      # 'Hello' (from beginning)
print(text[7:])      # 'World!' (to end)
print(text[-6:-1])   # 'World'
print(text[::2])     # 'Hlo ol!' (every 2nd char)
print(text[::-1])    # '!dlroW ,olleH' (reversed)
```

## String Length

```python
text = "Hello"
print(len(text))  # 5

# Empty string has length 0
print(len(""))    # 0
```

## String Concatenation

```python
# Using +
first = "Hello"
second = "World"
full = first + " " + second

# Using *
repeat = "Ha" * 3  # "HaHaHa"
```

## Common String Methods

```python
text = "  Hello World  "

print(text.lower())      # "  hello world  "
print(text.upper())      # "  HELLO WORLD  "
print(text.strip())      # "Hello World" (removes whitespace)
print(text.replace("World", "Python"))
print(text.find("World")) # Index of substring (or -1)
```
code:
# String Basics - Examples

print("String Basics")
print("="*50)

# Creating strings
print("\n1. Creating Strings:")
single = 'Single quotes'
double = "Double quotes"
multi = """Multi-line
string here"""
print(f"   Single: {single}")
print(f"   Double: {double}")
print(f"   Multi-line: {repr(multi)}")

# Indexing and slicing
print("\n2. Indexing and Slicing:")
text = "Python"
print(f"   Text: '{text}'")
print(f"   text[0] = '{text[0]}'")
print(f"   text[-1] = '{text[-1]}'")
print(f"   text[0:3] = '{text[0:3]}'")
print(f"   text[::-1] = '{text[::-1]}' (reversed)")

# String length
print("\n3. String Length:")
print(f"   len('Hello') = {len('Hello')}")

# Concatenation and repetition
print("\n4. Concatenation & Repetition:")
print(f"   'Hello' + ' World' = '{'Hello' + ' World'}'")
print(f"   'Hi! ' * 3 = '{'Hi! ' * 3}'")

# Case methods
print("\n5. Case Methods:")
text = "hello world"
print(f"   Original: '{text}'")
print(f"   .upper(): '{text.upper()}'")
print(f"   .title(): '{text.title()}'")
print(f"   .capitalize(): '{text.capitalize()}'")

# Strip whitespace
print("\n6. Strip Whitespace:")
padded = "   Hello!   "
print(f"   Original: '{padded}'")
print(f"   .strip(): '{padded.strip()}'")

# Find and replace
print("\n7. Find and Replace:")
text = "Hello, World!"
print(f"   Text: '{text}'")
print(f"   .find('World') = {text.find('World')}")
print(f"   .replace('World', 'Python') = '{text.replace('World', 'Python')}'")

# Split and join
print("\n8. Split and Join:")
csv = "apple,banana,cherry"
fruits = csv.split(",")
print(f"   '{csv}'.split(',') = {fruits}")
print(f"   ' - '.join(fruits) = '{' - '.join(fruits)}'")

# Validation methods
print("\n9. Validation Methods:")
print(f"   'abc'.isalpha() = {'abc'.isalpha()}")
print(f"   '123'.isdigit() = {'123'.isdigit()}")
print(f"   'abc123'.isalnum() = {'abc123'.isalnum()}")
